questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests impaired expiratory flow. Chest imaging shows reveal hyperinflation. Which type of emphysema is most commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Centriacinar

 

Option B:

 

Centriacinar emphysema predominantly affects the central or proximal part of the acinus, sparing the peripheral parts. It is commonly associated with cigarette smoking. It has the maximum prevalence clinically.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Panacinar Emphysema: Panacinar emphysema involves the destruction of the entire respiratory acinus, including the respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. It is often associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Option C. Paraseptal Emphysema: Paraseptal emphysema, also known as distal acinar emphysema, involves the distal parts of the acinus, particularly the alveolar ducts and alveoli near the pleura. It often occurs adjacent to scars or fibrotic tissue, and it is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Segmental Emphysema: Segmental emphysema refers to localized areas of emphysematous changes within a lung segment. It can occur in association with scarring or inflammation. While it is less common than other types of emphysema, it may contribute to localized airflow obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centriacinar emphysema, is most commonly associated with cigarette smoking and predominantly affects the central parts of the acinus, leading to symptoms like progressive dyspnea and chronic cough in smokers.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 678)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic cough and sputum production presents to the clinic. Pulmonary function tests reveal airway obstruction with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. He reports a smoking history of 30 pack-years. Which of the following conditions is most likely contributing to an increased Reid's index in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chronic bronchitis

 

Reid's index is a measure of the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal glands to the thickness of the bronchial wall. It is used to assess hypertrophy of submucosal glands in bronchi.

 

Option C:

 

Chronic bronchitis: Chronic bronchitis is associated with increased mucus production and inflammation. It can lead to an increased Reid's index due to hypertrophy of submucosal glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bronchiectasis: In bronchiectasis, there is irreversible dilation of the bronchi. Reid's index is typically not a prominent feature in bronchiectasis.

 

Option B: Bronchial asthma: Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction and inflammation. Reid's index is usually not significantly increased in bronchial asthma.

 

Option D: Emphysema: Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls, leading to airspace enlargement. Reid's index is not a characteristic feature of emphysema.

 

Educational objective:

 

Reid's index is a measure of the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal glands to the thickness of the bronchial wall that is a characteristic of chronic bronchitis.

 

Normal value: < 0.4

 

In chronic bronchitis: > 0.5 due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous glands

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 681)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a chronic cough and dyspnea. The sputum analysis reveals the presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals. Which of the following respiratory conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchial asthma

 

Option A:

 

Bronchial asthma have the sputum findings like Charcot-Leyden crystals (needle-shaped crystals composed of eosinophilic membrane protein) and Curschmann's spirals (spiral-shaped mucus plugs formed by the shedding of the bronchial mucosa).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chronic bronchitis is characterized by inflammation of the bronchi, leading to increased mucus production and a persistent cough.

 

Option C: Bronchiectasis: In bronchiectasis, there is irreversible dilation of the bronchi.

 

Option D: Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls and airspace enlargement.

 

However, Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals are not typically associated with chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis and emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals in sputum is characteristic of bronchial asthma, reflecting eosinophilic inflammation and shedding of the bronchial mucosa, respectively, and are not typically found in chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, or emphysema.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 685)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and cough. She has a history of asthma and is afebrile. On examination, her lungs show diffuse wheezing and decreased air entry. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of her inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leukotrienes

 

Option B:

 

Leukotrienes are lipid mediators that are produced by activated leukocytes, including mast cells and eosinophils, in response to inflammation. In patients with asthma, leukotrienes contribute to bronchial constriction, mucus secretion, and airway inflammation.

 

Leukotrienes, also products of arachidonic acid metabolism, are potent bronchoconstrictors and play a key role in the pathophysiology of asthma. They lead to increased mucus secretion, edema, and airway inflammation, contributing significantly to the clinical manifestations of asthma, including wheezing and shortness of breath.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prostaglandins are eicosanoids derived from arachidonic acid that can cause vasodilation and increase the permeability of blood vessels. They can play a role in inflammation and are associated with pain and fever, but they are not the most significant mediators in bronchoconstriction associated with asthma.

 

Option C. Histamine is released by mast cells and plays a significant role in immediate hypersensitivity reactions. It can cause bronchoconstriction, increase vascular permeability, and cause smooth muscle contraction, but it is not the primary mediator in ongoing asthmatic responses.

 

Option D. IL-6 is a cytokine involved in the acute-phase reaction and plays a role in chronic inflammation and autoimmunity. While it is involved in systemic inflammation, it is not a major direct mediator of bronchoconstriction in asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of asthma, leukotrienes are critical mediators that contribute to bronchial constriction, mucus secretion, and airway inflammation, leading to symptoms like wheezing and shortness of breath.

questions.text: Collapse of lung is seen as a feature of called:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Atelectasis

Option C:

 Atelectasis refers either to incomplete expansion of the lungs (neonatal atelectasis) or to the collapse of previously inflated lung, producing areas of relatively airless pulmonary parenchyma.

Bronchitis: Bronchitis is inflammation of the bronchial tubes, leading to increased production of mucus and cough.

Explanation:

Option A: Emphysema: Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls, leading to enlarged air spaces and loss of elastic recoil in the lungs.

Option B: Bronchiectasis: Bronchiectasis involves the abnormal widening of the bronchi, usually associated with chronic respiratory infections.

Educational Objective:

Atelectasis refers to the collapse of previously inflated lung tissue, resulting in airless areas within the pulmonary parenchyma, often visible as denser areas on a chest X-ray.

 

(Ref: Robins 10th/ 672)

questions.text: In a heavy smoker, which of the following is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Centrilobular emphysema

Option A:

Centriacinar emphysema predominantly affects the central or proximal part of the acinus, sparing the peripheral parts. It is commonly associated with cigarette smoking. It has the maximum prevalence clinically.

Explanation:

Option B: Panacinar emphysema involves the destruction of the entire respiratory acinus, including the respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. It is often associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Option C: Paraseptal emphysema, also known as distal acinar emphysema, involves the distal parts of the acinus, particularly the alveolar ducts and alveoli near the pleura. It often occurs adjacent to scars or fibrotic tissue, and it is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax.

Option D: Segmental emphysema refers to localized areas of emphysematous changes within a lung segment. It can occur in association with scarring or inflammation. While it is less common than other types of emphysema, it may contribute to localized airflow obstruction.

Educational Objective:

Centrilobular emphysema is the type of emphysema most commonly associated with chronic cigarette smoking, characterized by predominant damage to the central or proximal parts of the acini while sparing the peripheral alveoli, with the highest clinical prevalence.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 680)

choices.text: Alpha1 antitrypsin deficiency is important in its pathogenesis

questions.text: A 40 year male complains of chronic cough with expectoration of foul smelling sputum on and off since 6 months. He also has moderate dyspnea. The pathology of his lung is represented alongside. What statement best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Common in lower lobes

Option D:

The pulmonary pathology shown is bronchiectasis wherein dilated, thickened bronchioles can be followed up to the periphery of the lung. It is common in lower lobes due to pooling of secretions. The main causes of bronchiectasis are obstruction and necrotizing infections.

Explanation:

Option A: Alpha 1 anti trypsin is implicated in pathogenesis of emphysema. 

Option C: Airway remodeling occurs in bronchial asthma.

Option B: Reid index is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Educational Objective:

Bronchiectasis is characterized by dilated, thickened bronchioles and is commonly found in the lower lobes of the lung, where gravity assists in the pooling of secretions that contribute to the disease process.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 695)

questions.text: A leading pharmacological company Cerebellum Pharma wants to manufacture drugs to treat bronchospasm seen in bronchial asthma. An antagonist of which of the mediators is likely to be effective in acute phase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Leukotrienes C4, D4 and E4

Option C:

Leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4 are potent mediators of bronchoconstriction and increased mucin production, making them central to the pathophysiology of acute asthma attacks.

Explanation:

Option A: Interleukin 5 (IL-5) is involved in the late phase reaction of asthma by promoting eosinophil activation and survival, but it is not a direct mediator of acute bronchospasm.

Option B: Platelet-activating factor (PAF) has a role in increasing vascular permeability and may contribute to inflammation associated with asthma, but it is not the primary mediator of acute bronchospasm.

Option D: Complement C3a is involved in the inflammatory response and can cause bronchospasm as part of an allergic reaction, but it is less specific to asthma than leukotrienes.

Educational Objective:

Leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4 are the key mediators of acute bronchospasm in bronchial asthma, which makes them a prime target for antagonism in the acute treatment of the disease.

questions.text: A 30 year old male has had increasing dyspnea for the past 5 years. On physical examination, he had decreased breath sounds in all lung fields. X ray chest shows flattened diaphragm and increased lucency in all lung fields. Pulmonary function tests shows decreased FEV1 and increased FVC.  His younger brother also has similar complaints. What is the likely mechanism of his pulmonary pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reduced antielastase activity

Option B:

  • His history suggests panacinar emphysema. Alpha 1 antitrypsin is the major anti elastase and its deficiency is inherited disease (brother also having it) and causes panacinar emphysema.

Explanation:

Option A: CFTR gene mutation leads to cystic fibrosis and bronchiectasis.

Option C: Infection with TB does not cause emphysema but apical lobe cavitation.

Option D: Increased neutrophil elastases are increased with smoking but this emphysema is limited to upper lobes known as centriacinar emphysema. 

Educational Objective:

A reduced anti-elastase activity due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is likely responsible for panacinar emphysema, especially in non-smokers with a family history of similar symptoms.

choices.text: Positive family history seen
May be triggered by rhinovirus

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding non- atopic asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. May be triggered by rhinovirus

Option D:

May be triggered by rhinovirus – Non-atopic asthma can indeed be triggered by viral infections like the rhinovirus, which is a known common cause for exacerbations of asthma in individuals without allergic sensitization.

Explanation:

Option A: Allergen sensitization present – This typically pertains to atopic asthma, where there is a hypersensitivity reaction to environmental allergens, unlike non-atopic asthma.

Option B: Positive family history seen – While a positive family history can be a risk factor for asthma, it is more strongly associated with atopic rather than non-atopic asthma.

Option C: IgE levels raised – Elevated IgE levels are a hallmark of atopic asthma, which is associated with an allergic type of asthma and not commonly elevated in non-atopic asthma.

Educational Objective:

Non-atopic asthma is not primarily triggered by allergens and does not typically present with elevated IgE levels or allergen sensitization, but can be exacerbated by viral infections such as rhinovirus.
